column2: re this Tutorial / Exercise on : Facebook
t is a segmentation fault?

mentation fault is a specific kind of error caused by accessing memory that "does not belong to you." It's a helper mechanism that keeps you from corrupting the memory and introducing hard-to-debug memory bugs. Whenever you get a segfault you know you are doing something wrong with memory - accessing a variable that has already been freed
column3: writing to a read-only portion of the memory
column4: etc. Segmentation fault is essentially the same in most languages that let you mess with memory management
column5: there is no principal difference between segfaults in C and C++.

column2: re are many ways to get a segfault
column3: at least in the lower-level languages such as C(++). A common way to get a segfault is to dereference a null pointer:

column2: ther segfault happens when you try to write to a portion of memory that was marked as read-only:
r *str = "Foo"; // Compiler marks the constant string as read-only
r = 'b'; // Which means this is illegal and results in a segfault
gling pointer points to a thing that does not exist anymore
pointer p dangles because it points to the character variable c that ceased to exist after the block ended. And when you try to dereference dangling pointer (like *p='A')
column3: you would probably get a segfault.
